captions.text:
PAUL SMITH: And then when they
get to 70, that's where the

big problems start, because the
French haven't invented a
word for 70.

BRADY HARAN: I always assume the
one thing that is kind of

international is numbers,
mathematics.

That's the one thing that
is the same everywhere.

You're about to ruin
this, aren't you?
PAUL SMITH: Yes, I am.

One thing that you learn when
you're studying a foreign

language is that counting
systems are very different.

And, in fact, it's one of the
ways that you can tell if

somebody's a really good speaker
of a foreign language.

You can really tell what their
real mother tongue is when

they start counting, because
even if somebody operates, you

know, an English person living
in France, when they start

counting to themselves, they'll
probably count to
themselves in English.

They're our closest neighbors,
so you'd have thought that

maybe they'd count in
the same way as us.

But one of the things that I
have to keep repeating to my

students is that, in fact,
the French don't
count in the same way.

And they use numbers in very
different ways in a whole

range of different everyday
environments.
Let me give you some examples.

So the French-- well, what do
we do in England when we're
counting numbers?

We give numbers, the first 12
numbers when we're counting,
we give them individual names.
So we go 1 to 12.

And then we slip into a thing
where we go 13, 14, which is

kind of 3 and 10, 4 and
10, and so forth.

The French start off in a
slightly different way.
They go a bit further.

Un, deux, trois, quatre, cinq,
six, sept, huit, neuf, dix,

onze, douze, treize, quatorze,
quinze, seize.

And then they go for our 17,
dix-sept, 10-7; dix-huit,

10-8; dix-neuf, 10-9; and
then vingt for 20.

It's very similar, the
counting system
after that, to English.

So they go on to 20, as
I said was vingt.
Then they go to 30, trente.
Quarante for 40.
Cinquante for 50.
Soixante for 60.

And then when they get to 70,
that's where the big problems

start, because the
French haven't
invented a word for 70.

Instead what they do is they
count to 60 and add 10.

So whereas we go to 60 and then
go to 70, a French person

goes to 60, but then goes to 60
plus 10, because they say
soixante-dix.
Soixante-dix is 70 in French.

Soixante-dix literally means
60-10, but it means 70.

Oh, they know what
the number 70 is.

They don't sort of do
this plus business.

And a French person, when they
hear you say soixante-dix,

they don't think, oh,
that's 60 and 10.
They see 70.

So the mental picture that is
conjured by the sound of

soixante-dix is still 70,
the same as we would.

And then they continue by
instead of say-- they haven't

invented a word, for
example, for 71.

So that's soixante et onze,
literally 60 and 11.

It's rather odd with these
ones that they
say soixante et onze--
"et" is the word for "and"--

because when they get to 72,
they just say soixante-douze.
Soixante-douze, 60-12.

And it's only when we're dealing
with ones that they
use the "et."

But it gets even more confusing
from the English

point of view, because you
think, OK, so we've got

Soixante et onze,
soixante-douze,

soixante-treize,
soixante-quatorze,

soixante-quinze,
soixante-seize,

soixante-dix-sept,
soixante-dix-huit,
soixante-dix-neuf.

What do they do when
they get to 80?

Surely they've got
a word for 80.
Well, no.

Because the French, when they
get to that number, they say

quatre-vingts, which
means 4 20s.

Well, that's what it means,
4 20s, literally.

The French, of course, when they
hear quatre-vingts, see
80 in their minds.

And then they go
quatre-vingt-un, 4 20s, 1.
BRADY HARAN: Not 4 20s and 1?
PAUL SMITH: No.
They'd just be-- ah.

The reason they don't say 4 20s
and 1 is because it's too
many words.

So there's also a style issue
here, because, you know, the
French love their style.

But what they do do then, and
this is the other weird thing,

when they get to 90, they still
haven't even thought of

another word for 90 or
a decent word for 90.
So what do they say?

They say quatre-vingt-dix,
4 20s, 10.

And then when they get
to 91, they say
quatre-vingt-onze, 4 20s, 11.
92 is quatre-vingt-douze.
93 is quatre-vingt-treize.
94 is quatre-vingt-quatorze.
95, quatre-vingt-quinze.

And so it goes, until
they get up to 100.

And they have invented
a word for 100.
So 100 is cent.

One of the big problems, of
course, with this kind of

numbering system is when you're
listening to somebody

giving you a phone number,
because if
I could just explain--

let me think of an English
phone number.

So you might have 0115, so
that's your Nottingham code.

Then you'd have 962 would be the
subcode for the exchange.

And then the individual
number would be 5782.

And in English, we would read
out all of the numbers,

0-1-1-5, or we might say
0-double 1-5, 962, 5782.

BRADY HARAN: This isn't a real
number, by the way, is it?
PAUL SMITH: No, no.
I just made that one up.
OK.

So that's an example of an
English telephone number.

But in France, they do it
completely differently.

They will take the numbers and
they will say they will

actually distinguish the
numbers 62, 58, 49, 27.

And when you ask somebody for
their phone number, they will

tell you that it is
62, 58, 49, 27.
They won't say--

BRADY HARAN: They'll do that
for all numbers, will they?

PAUL SMITH: They'll do that
for all telephone numbers.
They won't say 625-849-27.

And this causes not big
problems, but if you're on the

telephone to a client in France
who wants your mobile

number and you're used to giving
your mobile number in

the way the English do and then
you try to do it to the

French, they find that very
difficult to cope with.

And it works in the
other direction.

My students are endlessly
telling me about the problems

they had copying down
telephone numbers.

And of course, the really big
problems start when you get to

numbers that start with
a 6, with a 7, with an
8, and with a 9.

So it's a problem, because
if you're English
and you hear soixante--

let's remember that numbers,
what we would call 60 to 69,
start with the word soixante.
But so do numbers 70 to 79.

Let's say that your friend
starts saying "my number is"--

I'll say it in French,
"mon numero, c'est
soixante" you start--
you do that.

And then they say "et onze" and
you have to go back and

correct it, because it's not
soixante at all, it's 71.

But the other thing that the
French do with numbers while

we're on the subject, that's the
French for "10 point 69."

Let's say that that's the world
record for the women's

100 meters dash in
the Olympics.

Now you can see that's very
different from the way that we
would write it in English.

It's also very different from
the way that we would say it.

There we've got a
decimal point.

And the French are
using a comma.

But they also say
it differently.

In English we say "10 point 69,"
because we separate the
tenths and the hundredths.

But the French would
say "10 comma 69."

So you have to listen
now very carefully.

If you're watching a French
sports commentary, for

example, if you're watching the
Olympic Games in France

and you're trying to catch the
time, you have to listen out

for not 10 point 69, but "dix
virgule soixante-neuf," "10

comma 69." So once again,
you've got this issue of

numbers being grouped
together.

And that's something the
French do all the time.

They don't separate individual
numbers out.

They group them and
use their name.

The word the French use for a
comma is "virgule." And they

use that in grammar as they
use it in numbers as well.

So when a French person reads
out this time, then they will
say "dix virgule"--
comma--
"soixante-neuf."

BRADY HARAN: To a French person,
is that "10 point 695"
or is that 10,695?

PAUL SMITH: It's 10,
virgule, 695.

So it would be "dix virgule six
cent quatre-vingt-quinze."

That would be the way
they express it.

BRADY HARAN: How would a French
person write 10,695?

PAUL SMITH: Well, they would
either just do that--

and very often they
leave a space.

In a French textbook you might
find there's a space between
the thousands and the 695.

Or occasionally, this is going
to confuse you, just
occasionally they'll do that.

So in fact, you could say that
the French and the English do
exactly the opposite thing.

And you could argue that it's
just to confuse each other and
it's deliberate.

Well, I don't have a problem
with it, but it has caused
problems in the past.

There was a rather unfortunate
case in a French hospital a

few years ago where there
was a serious--

too large a dose of something
was administered to patients

simply because of a misreading
of a decimal point for this,

or a comma not being read
the right way round.

So it can be a big problem
in technical translation.

Technical translators need to
be absolutely sure that they

get it right, because
otherwise it can
go very, very wrong.

BRADY HARAN: If you'd like to
hear a bit more about French

numbers, including why it's
impossible to score 20 out of

20 in France, check out another
video we've got here

on "Numberphile." Or if you'd
just like to hear more about

languages in general from people
like Paul and others,

check out another channel I've
got called "Words of the

World." It's got all sorts of
fascinating videos about

things like California
or biscuit or vodka.

There's loads of videos on there
already and there's new

ones going on every week,
so maybe subscribe.

comments.author: Killian Le Matheux

comments.text:
"Cent" ins't that odd, look at the word for %.

5:30  our phone number system was simply based since 1996 on a geographical 
system, the two first digits are used for the zone, the other also pinpoint 
a smaller zone in that said zone. this is why most of french will break a 
phone number this way.

When writting a phone number we might aswell write it in one go or use "." 
or "-" every two digits. when it comes to numbers in other case (like math) 
we don't break numbers this way.﻿

so polish numbers are really easy.﻿

comments.text:
In french speaking Switzerland we do not follow the crazy French "method" 
We use "septante" for 70 and "huitante" for 80 (although in some area we 
use "quatre-vingt" for 80)
Same goes for 90 wich is, here, "nonante". It follows the same logic 
english speakers use: seventy / seven _ septante / sept, and so on.

Sacrés Français ^^﻿

comments.author: Joao Ventura

comments.text:
Oh man... In Greece we also say numbers after the decimal like that, but 
like... what if you want to say pi? I've never heard anyone say more digits 
than 3.14 (or 3,14 as we would write it), but if you wanted to say 
3.1415926535 (which is how much I remember) you would have to say "τρία 
κόμμα ένα δισεκατομύριο τετρακόσια δεκαπέντε εκατομύρια εννιακόσιες 
εικοσιέξι χιλιάδες πεντακόσια τριανταπέντε" which is longer compared to 
"τρία κόμμα ένα τέσσερα ένα πέντε εννέα δύο έξι πέντε τρία πέντε". You 
might say it's not that much longer but imagine spelling out many more 
digits than that and having to check the length of the string of digits and 
then imagining separations for every three digits etc. I personally never 
say numbers the "regular" way, but then again I'm not really native Greek 
:P﻿

comments.author: Merill Gilbert

comments.text:
For the majority of the historians it comes from the gallic tribes that 
were using a vicesimal (base 20) numeric system. Although Gallic langage 
was replaced by Roman which later on evolved into French, peoples kept 
their way of thinking and adapted it in the new langage.
For instance During a large part of middle age 30 (trente in french) was 
"vingt et dix" (twenty and ten), 40 was "deux vingt" (two twenty), 50 was 
"deux vingt et dix" (two twenty and ten), 60 was "trois vingt" (three 
twenty).﻿

comments.author: Kall Drogo

comments.text:
Just a fun thing: in Quebec, we use the same phone number system as the 
rest of Canada and the United States, so over here, we rarely break the 
numbers in two numbers group, only when it is already like that... for 
example, say the phone number 536-982-8374 would be said by numbers, but 
536-982-8383 would be said "cinq trois six, neuf huit deux, quatre-vingt 
trois quatre-vingt trois" because it gets less confusing on the phone than 
"huit trois huit trois"﻿
comments.author: Philippe Gilbert

comments.text:
Actually there are French words for 70, 80, 90: septante, octante (or 
huitante) and nonante, but they are used in Belgium and Switzerland. The 
king Louis XIV decided that the French people should only say the names we 
are seeing in this vid. And we could also talk about  Germans who say the 
units before the tens. On my calculator, the chains of 3 digits are 
separated by an apostrophe, which is a clear notation with no confusion 
possible. We could also talk about Americans who refuse to adopt the metric 
system but are rather introducing the decimal notation in pounds and inches 
to replace complicated fractions, using mils (1/1000 ") instead of microns 
and using calories for nutrition but BTUs for BBQ, heaters or climatizers. 
They started to install dual system signs on roads for distances ans speed 
limits and got back to miles-only signs.﻿
comments.author: korelly

comments.author: James Scales

comments.text: German do it the French way﻿
comments.author: JihHou Peh

comments.text:
I understood that the 20 thing had to do with the way the Celtic number 
system worked. If you look at the way Danish does numbers you can see that 
their 50, 70, and 90 have "halv" in them, suggesting to someone who doesn't 
speak any Danish that their system is based on a unit of 20 too - vigesimal 
(apparently the word for that) as opposed to decimal. Also in English 
people did say things like 3 score and ten, so English and French are not 
that far apart really. Also there are differences between English English 
and American English - we (in the UK) say one hundred and ten, whereas in 
the US I think the "and" is not said, so we too have our difficulties. 
Lastly it's interesting to see that the Japanese number system doesn't work 
in thousands but in tens of thousands - a million is hyaku man - 1 hundred 
ten-thousand. The way to say numbers can be quite complicated? Oh, a last 
also - in Switzerland septante, huitante, nonante are used and in Belgium 
septante and nonante.﻿
comments.author: Allen Conway

comments.text: 80 blaze it﻿
comments.author: ALifeOfGames

comments.text:
Iirc, the gramatically correct way to say those numbers would be the swiss 
and belgian ones, based on latin. Septante, octante and nonante.

But in Paris in the middle ages people (merchants mostly) used the base 20 
to count, something you pointed out in the video about the marking system 
(20/20). And apparently this habit took roots in the french administration 
and from there into "standard" french.
That's why we have quatre-vingt and quatre-vingt-dix and by mimestim, 
soixante-dix. But also places like the hospital  "des quinze-vingt" (read 
of the 15x20 = 300, a hospital that could house 300 blind people when it 
was built)﻿
comments.author: Keyser Pacha

comments.text:
So does that mean French people would say (imagine this in French)

'one comma one million six hundred and thirty four thousand one hundred and 
twenty seven' instead of
'one point one six three four one two seven'﻿
comments.author: MilkBlauk7

comments.text:
+MilkBlauk7 In theory yes haha, but when it's a long number, we say them 
one by one such as you, because we don't want to lose too much time reading 
the whole number. Most of the time we group them when they are two or three.
comments.author: meumpopeur

comments.text:
+MilkBlauk7 Yes we do, but actually, unlike all the rest (such as the four 
twenties and one which is totally retarded), it does kind of make 
sense.Said that way, as you are treating the number in its whole you can 
easily grasp its size and properties, whereas if you spell it digit by 
digit well... you can easily lose track of the value. It's easier to 
picture the number as a whole (for instance, if I say one dot a million and 
one) I instantly know what my number will look like, but if you say one dot 
one zero zero zero zero zero one it may be confusing, and is actually 
harder to spell and count.

four-twenty, it's a name not a number, it composed name like in english 
when you say seahorse (sea + horse). We didn't give a word to "80", we gave 
it a name and it's pronounced "quatrevingts" in speaking language, just 
like a normal name, we did the same for 70 and 90.﻿

comments.text:
Chinese numbers are easy
1一.  2.二  3.三  4.四  5.五  6.六  7.七  8.八  9.九  10.十
11.十一(ten one)  12.十二(ten two).......19.十九(ten nine)20.二十(two ten)
21.二十一(two ten one)  22.二十二(two ten two)..... 30.三十(three ten)
.......98.九十八(nine ten eight)  99.九十九(nine ten nine)  100一百(one hundred)
101.一百零一(one hundred zero one)  102.一百零二(one hundred zero two)
110.一百一十(one hundred one ten) 111.一百一十一(one hundred one ten one)
Ex.563 五百六十三(five hundred six ten three)
     711 七百一十一(seven hundred one ten one),not seven eleven

BUT! there is something you have to notice
100                       一百
1000                     一千
10000                   一[萬]  we don't use 十千(ten thousand)
10,0000                十[萬]  we don't use 百千(hundred thousand)
100,0000              一百[萬]  we don't use million
1000,0000            一千[萬]  we don't use ten million
1,0000,0000         一[億]
1,0000,0000,0000一[兆]﻿
comments.author: .劉蝦毀

comments.text:
There is also a simple explanation for why there is "et" in 
"soixante-et-onze" (71) and not in "quatre-vingt-un" (81) or 
"quatre-vingt-onze" (91) and it's not about using less words but about 
pronunciation. 
In French you use "et" to make the junction with the next word when the 
word before ends with an "e" like in soixantE, but also in trentE 
(trente-et-un) 31 or a lot of other numbers. For 81 or 91, "vingt" ends 
with a "t" so you don't use "et" to make the jonction and only say 
"quatre-vingt-onze".
It's a bit the same as the difference between "a" and "an" in English: "a 
boat" but "an elephant".

But French love exceptions so there is one and it's for 21 "vingt-et-un" 
even if "vingt" doesn't end with an "e". It's because in that case "vingt" 
is pronounced exactly as if it was written "vinte" so you have to use an 
"et".﻿

comments.author: Gene Hunter

comments.text:
Abraham Lincoln: "Four-score and seven years..."
four-score (i.e. 4x20) = 80 = quatre-vingts (French)

Traditional English nursery rhyme: "Four and twenty blackbirds..."
four and twenty = 24 = vier und zwanzig (German)

It's true that these terms are not used in modern English, but the French 
and German ways of counting should be neither surprising nor confusing to 
any educated English speaker.﻿
comments.author: manbat76

comments.text:
The Germans also use a comma (komma) for a decimal point; and I belive that 
most of the rest of Europe does as well.

But the way the English have written a decimal point has changed over the 
years.  When I was a lad, mumble years ago, a decimal point was not written 
the same as a full stop.  A decimal point was written like the top half of 
a colon, without the bottom half, if you see what I mean.  However, most 
manual typewriters did not have this option so used a full stop as an 
approximation - which seems to have caught on as this laptop keyboard can't 
do a classical decimal point, either.﻿

i admit that it can be weird but... french is such a beautiful language !
JUST MY OPINION !!
i love english, and... Sorry, but... French is much more beautiful than

sometimes, when i really like a book, i read it twice : the fist time in

JUST MY OPINION !!﻿

90 is either : nonante or quatre-vingts-dix

comments.author: Hippolyte Menou

comments.text:
Well, this has already been said, but I think it's important: there are 
other (and easier) words for 70, 80, 90 in French.
70 = septante, 80 = huitante, 90 = nonante

That's the way French speakers count in Switzerland and Belgian people use 
'septante' and 'nonante' too. French people usually know and understand 
them so learners from other countries could learn the Swiss way of counting 
and be fine.﻿
